texts.shortText: Large, unattached scallop with lower (right) valve strongly convex and upper (left) one flat, 12-15 strong radiating ridges on each shell. Distinct ‘ear’ on both sides of straight hinge. Colour mottled cream and pink, often paler in older individuals.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to East London.

Lies on clean sandy substrata at depths of about 22-84 m with the curved right valve always downwards. When disturbed capable of sustained swimming by clapping the shell valves together and expelling jets of water. Swimming direction can be controlled by opening and closing different parts of the mantle edge.  The curved shape of the lower shell ensures that the scallop always settles right way up after a bout of swimming. Edge of the mantle decorated with a series of conspicuous shiny simple eyes, each borne at the base of a sensory tentacle. These are used to sense the presence of predators.

Large scallops are highly sought after as seafood and this species is certainly big enough to be eaten, but the wild stocks are too small to sustain a commercial fishery. There has, however, been recent interest in culturing this species for human consumption and growth rates attained in culture are comparable to those found in other famed species.

All bivalves feed by drawing water in, then filtering it thought the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the edge of the gill and then to the mouth.
Like almost all bivalves scallops are broadcast spawners. The spawning season in this species is from June to September each year.

This is the only common large scallop likely to be encountered on Western Cape, but several other similar species occur in the warmer waters off KwaZulu-Natal and at deeper depths (for details see references below).
